								Below you'll find both a written and a video impressions on the game


YouTube™ Video: Darkwood: Early Impressions 

			Views: 583		

			Darkwood: Early Impressions Darkwood video created on version: Alpha 1.0 Darkwood takes the survival horror genre to a top down perspective and throws in some optional "rogue-like/lite" elements.		

 As an early access Darkwood is fairly solid. I didn't find any bugs or glitches, and the game never crashed. It does suffer from some optimization issues, mainly the long load time. As for the game it self, it's pretty enjoyable, if not, at least a unique experience. Darkwood takes the survival horror genre and put it into a top down perspective, with an excellent aesthetic style. Visually the game is of a high caliber. The background and foreground elements are detailed and stylized, while still maintaining visual clarity so the player can easily decipher what items are interactable. The game's sound design is equally admirable. Your footsteps sound realistic and heavy, with the ground it treads on matching the steps you take. You'll hear random twig snaps, and kicks of pebbles. Crows in the distance, and animals in the shrubs, with a light but moody sound track to kick in the appropriate moments, and you have a game that's a real treat for the ears, as well as the eyes. The game's sinister atmosphere is further echoed by the use of light, both for visual interest as well as using light as a mechanics on it's own.The game also features an interesting chapter by chapter story structure as well, with the current build being the prologue. With out giving too much away, let's say at the game's first turning point, a fairly major and unexpected reviel will instantly grab your curiosity.  Though the game is quite enjoyable even at this early stage, it's not with out it's faults. On the technical side. long load times can drive a person's patience, and the game's lack of features and options is also worth noting. Mechanically speaking once you start playing with the more sandboxy elements of the game, you could find yourself in long stretches wandering seemingly aimlessly, wondering where your next objective is, or if you're even going the "right" way. To be fair, this isn't so much a problem with Darkwood it self, but rather, a common issue with survival games in general.Overall the game is a quality product already, and I can only see it getting better with time. I believe I can safely recommend Darkwood if you are interested in the idea of a top-down sandbox-ish survival horror.Pros:- Great graphics- Interesting plot- A new take on survival horror- Great sound design- Good lightingCons:- Long load times- Can get boring when searching for next objective- Limited features and options

Early Access Review
								This is gonna be a long one so I'm gonna summarize here. If you're looking for a perfect blend of sandbox and horror then this game will definitely tickle your fancy. I highly recommend it even if it is early access. Normally I hate early access. People throwing out unfinished games to the masses. This is the one exception. Don't hesitate in getting this now if you're interested. It's damn good and feels like a finished game.Day oneFirst day of the game I was terrified. I had no idea when night was coming. My inventory was full and I quickly realized my map doesn't show my exact position. I had to figure it out on my own using landmarks I've located. This was my first major mistake. I was lost. I could see the sun was beginning to set and I was still lost deep within the woods. I was so cocky. When I first booted the game I turned on permadeath thinking I could ace this game like any other horror or sandbox game I've played. None of them set the atmosphere quite like Darkwood did. Nothing frightened me more than seeing the sun come down. I began panicking, sprinting my way through the forest hoping for any sort of shelter. Of course I didn't find any. I did find the road however and with it, eventually my home. It was pitch dark outside and I made the huge mistake of leaving the generator on. I was so stupid. I assumed the gas I put in it would last longer or it'd just stop using fuel during the day. The typical gaming conventions I was used to wasn't present in this game. Not even the sight of my own home made me feel any relief. I'd made another horrible mistake. I hadn't had time to barricade the windows during the day. I shut myself in one of the rooms and pushed all manner of furniture in front of the doors and windows, hoping it'd keep whatever was out there away. I had no idea what I was up against. But I could hear them. I had run out of furniture to push against any openings. There was one window I had to keep open and for the rest of the night I stared at it from across the room. I spent the whole night, weapon raised, staring out that window terrified for my life.ReviewI've watched this game in development for a while and I was pleasantly surprised to see a developer actually deliver an amazing game for early access. I had my doubts. I really wanted to get this game when it was finished so I could get the whole experience but I couldn't resist any longer. Boy was I impressed though. It felt like a complete game. Of course I bought it shortly after most of the bugs had been squashed so I didn't really get to see how buggy it may have been early on. They've already thrown out so many bug fixes in the short amount of time it's been released that I definitely have high hopes for its development. A lot of "survival horror" game developers just don't get what makes a horror game truly terrifying. I've seen countless of these horror games that rely solely on jump scares or just putting the character in a dark room with a flashlight. And what few games have that right kind of atmosphere have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game-play. Darkwood does this flawlessly. Not only is it in a terrifying setting, but it's also fun to play. The most important thing to any horror media (be it a movie, book or game) is setting the tone. You need the player to feel immersed in this atmosphere or they won't give a damn about the character's well-being. I was genuinely scared I wouldn't be able to make it home the first night. I had absolutely no idea what I was up against and I didn't want to know. All I knew is that it wanted me dead. I wasn't even sure if the dressers I pressed against the doors and windows would even protect me from them. Its that mystery that makes the game so effective at being scary. Not once did I feel like I was truly safe. Even as the sun came up. All in all this was definitely one of the scariest experiences I've had with a game. I highly recommend it to anyone with a taste for horror. Darkwood will forever be my measuring stick for judging what a true survival horror game should be.

Early Access Review
								In terms of Early Access, I'm usually in favour of waiting for the full game to release. But there's a lot to like about Darkwood, even in the early Alpha 9.1 version that has sucked me in.The game is much more polished than when I tried it last (I think it was Alpha ~6 or thereabouts) and, at least in terms of the early chapters, seems pretty playable and largely functional as a "game".Okay, so enough about the development, is it fun to play?Oh god, yes. The game feels like an enmeshing of Don't Starve and Dark Souls (or perhaps classic Biohazard/Resident Evil) to me. With lots of small pixel detail thrown in. The sounds and the small details, like your character absently rubbing his arms, feels fleshed out like the little world on the screen is truly alive. And everything about it just feels kind of... off (in a good way). Sort of like when you first watched Don't Hug Me. I'm Scared videos. Well, except that the overt weirdness and horror is up front, that is. The tutorial helps you learn how to control the game, but after that, it doesn't really hold your hand. But this is largely a good thing, because it gives you a chance to learn what's going, on your own.And whatever is going on is weeeeiiird, in a very good way. Everything about it is unsettling, and leads you toward unsettling conclusions. The forest encroaches on everything, and everything has a twisted, sinister sheen to it. Like playing Nocturne, but, ahem, genuinely scary. So even though it's early access, I feel compelled to play it, and that's a very good thing in my book. If you liked the creepier parts of the tabletop RPGs Summerland, or Symbaroum, or have even gotten sucked into playing Noio's Kingdom for hours because of the base building and scavenging loop... you will be in good hands here. I think the systems and mechanics feel a lot like a tooled up version of The Last Stand flash games. You forage for materials during the day (sadly, so far I haven't encountered any other survivors willing to help me defend my hideout in the dark hours), and then hole up at night, just praying for dawn.I strongly recommend checking a wiki or a guide for some basics, otherwise it may feel frustrating. The game, at least on Normal difficulty, is forgiving just enough to not feel artificial. You'll breathe a sigh of relief when you find that lucky pile of wood to build your next barricade. But be sure not to "level up" via cooking too soon, or else you may find you'll be wasting precious resources on light... yes, at least in the version I played, if you skulk in the darkness of your hideout, in the beginning, you may survive okay.

Early Access Review
								While I would recommend this game for fans of atmospheric roguelikes and horror mysteries, I have to do so with a few big caveats. The top-down dark view the game uses makes it extremely difficult to tell what you're looking at to the point where half your time is spent bumping up against big gloomy objects. The day/night cycle isn't clearly defined so you never know when night is coming and you need to get back to your base, though I'm not sure it matters since there doesn't appear to be any penalty to dying so you might as well use it as a sort of quick-travel to get home. Combat is pretty clunky to the point where it feels awkward and punishing in a way that has nothing to do with difficulty.That said, the atmosphere and mood are absolutely stellar, especially in the opening prologue of the game, and the character artwork is amazing. It's clear that there's been a lot of thought towards making this a tense and difficult survival simulation with a real story to it, and it's a story that's a genuinely intriguing one too. The concept of exploring, hunting, scavenging, and barricading is solid, but at the moment my concern is that it seems like the biggest emphasis has been on style instead of polishing the gameplay mechanics. Yeah, I know, it's Early Access. I funded this last year. But playing a game, even a game that's intended to be a difficult one, shouldn't feel like an uphill battle where the game is fighting you instead of challenging you. With tweaks to its UI to provide more helpful feedback and a less obtuse combat system, Darkwood has a lot of potential, and I hope it lives up to it.

								EARLY REVIEW (Subject to change)Update: 4/10/2015 build 4.1 AlphaThe game is coming along nicely. With each build come new improvements to everything across the board. By now it can be hard to tell that this is not a finished product! Please help fund it. Buy it now while it's "finished" but under construction and help a cult classic come into being.---I waited since this was announced on Greenlight, and boy was it ever worth the wait. First off, the ATMOSPHERE. It is amazing. I didn't think a top-down experience could really capture it so well, but it does because you can see the environment around you, sometimes eerily twitching or waving if you aren't looking at it directly. You can hear the wind, an occasional shriek, eerie ambience and the occasional crunch of a branch that might make you jump. Be careful, the noises you make can attract horrifying things, and the oppressive environment makes that delightfully clear the moment you see it. Who knows what might be hiding behind those wavy branches in the background?Next comes the exploration. Getting lost is VERY easy to do, so once again the location and feeling of real fear is stressed by this risk. You must make it back by dark or you will die, so be sure to know your pathway back, and hope to high hell there aren't any -things- to block your path on the way back. Look for materials for crafting, barricading, repairing or boiling mushrooms into a drug of sorts that gives you skills (A sort of leveling system). Craft a weapon immediately when you find what you need. But even with that, you're bound to want to run and hide from most threats.The characters that I have seen so far have also been extremely interesting. Well designed, excellent art illustrates them and unsettling dialog helps highlight what remains of the populace in this story.HOWEVER, there -are- bugs, as to be expected from an alpha, and the best way to play is just to expect the unexpected and report something if it blocks your progress, quit and reload. The dev team is very on top of everything and listens well to the playerbase. With the arrival of Alpha 2.0, it's clear they love their game and are serious about making things better for the players.Ending thoughts - Worth a buy if you like to support indie development and love a good, unique horror game, because there really isn't anything else like it out there, and you'd be supporting something great.NOT worth a buy when not on sale if you can't tolerate bugs and would rather have a finished product, but this one's going to be a hit. Grab it if it happens to be cheap at the time.This is something worth supporting. There aren't many indie teams out there with such passion for their product, and I believe it's already showing with each small patch.So far: 8/10, and only because of bugs and missing features.

								This review is an early access one and will be subject to change as time goes by.So, Darkwood, its somethin alright.I've first bought this game on a lovely sale I think sometime back in 2014? Close to the release date? I'm not sure. Maybe I watched a youtuber play it and I bought it at some point. I dunno. But at any case, I've realized after all this time, I've spent about a full day total onto this very game. So, its appropriate enough for me to begin reviewing it.(Note, this may contain spoilers so if you dont want to risk it, dont read.)Darkwood is a top down perspective survival horror game. Though it gives limited vision, meaning you have to look all around you and be on your toes because this gives a sense of anxiousness. You dont know what might be across the field next to you, and you wont know that you're about to back into some poisonous mushrooms. This gives off an interesting feeling when you play the game, having to be purposely alert like in FNAF. The first one anyways, but I digress.Its focus on horror is mainly on my favorite, sound. You might hear footsteps in the distance, or at night you might hear some thumping noise or shreik just outside your door or barricaded window. You'll never know and thats what I love about it. The sound mixed in with limited vision gives such a dreadful feeling that something is there and you dont know if you should look or not.  Like at one point at night in this reviews more recent playthrough, I was minding my own business, just trying to wait the night out before I saw a light and noise just outside my house that was out of my characters vision. It was new and weird, so I went to investigate, and it was some kind of creature with red all around him, before it unfolds its arms and then releases birds/crows from under him before disappearing. This immediately got me nervous and I love that there is something that might be dangerous yet you dont know what it is. I love this fearful feeling. The combat.....its okay. Its a little finicky to handle because you have to wind up the attack all the way before swinging. And you dont get guns or things like that till mid game, but its a long way from where you would be depending if you're new to the game. I did find it annoying to having to wind up the attack all the way, making it difficult to judge when to swing. But thats just me. Maybe thats how it should be.The story wont be spoiled here, but I can try to describe it as best I can without spoiling. To me, its incomplete. But thats because its in early access and all.Speaking of, for an early access game, this is a long♥♥♥♥♥early access. I feel that the developers could put more time and energy into speeding the process up because this ambitious project is very, VERY ambitious. Tough to tackle too what with all that goes on in developing games. Though its none of my business, I would say that something like a kickstarter or funding program would greatly help get this game noticed more, and then get the support it needs to hurry its way out of early access. Because at this point, it might be in early access for a long long time, what with what they need to do to get all the story and game together.All and all, this game is one of my favorite horror games to this day. Though at first I hated it because trading was such a mess, but now with all that it is now, its at least fun, while at the same time challenging. And every time the developers FINALLY update it, its always a fun update to make me come back and play some more. Even though it makes my save game invalid due to the update, causing me to restart, it still feels worth it to see all the things they add into it. I give these guys my full support because what they got here is one of the most fun, exciting, heart pounding horror games I've ever played. The dreadful feeling of hearing a monster growl or make some sort of noise quickly makes me alert and at the same time, scared. All and all, if you crave a horror game and have a lot of time to spend (Seriously, you might spend quite a bit of time into this per session) while at the same time needing a new and fresh idea for a horror game, go buy this one. There wont be any regrets.Bonus: MAJOR SPOILS By the by, that one section where I had to go into the chapel and move around a literal horde of sleeping monsters was the most terrifying and unfavorite section of a horror game I've ever played. Please make more scary things. <3

 My review to Darkwood So what makes Darkwood different from other games that strive to unsettle you? Well, for starters, Darkwood doesn’t hinge on jump-inducing surprise-scares for its sense of tension (though it promises its fair share of these moments, anyways). Instead, Darkwood places you in a procedurally generated forest in a deeply twisted perversion of Soviet Russia. From there, the game’s dismal lighting, grotesque ambiance, and overall eerie atmosphere create the horror themselves.darkwood horror survival game gameplayIn other words, Darkwood doesn’t rely on cheap scare tactics and bursts of adrenaline to generate its terror. Darkwood’s brand of fear is the type that starts as a knot of unease in your stomach, a knot that grows tighter with each door you push slowly open, with every backwards glance and each spectral groan that floats out of the fog. Darkwood doesn’t try to scare you in the traditional Western sense – it tricks you into scaring yourself.Of course, we can’t talk about innovation in the genre without looking into the very thing that made the game stand out to me in the first place – its choice of perspective. Where most horror games seek to attach you to the protagonist by making you look through their eyes, Darkwood is the embodiment of detachment. You look down on your character from above, your line of sight limited to the swath of your flashlight beam.This means that behind you, inside buildings, anywhere that your light can’t reach, is blanketed in darkness. Nightmarish things lurk outside the light, things that you will be forced to encounter as you drift through the corrupted forest. Whether or not you survive these brushes with the frightful unknown is entirely up to you. What Else? In addition to the top-down view, Darkwood introduces some more interesting ideas. Its design has been inspired by rogue-like, adventure, and role-playing games alike, giving it a unique and nuanced feel that it seems only indie games can achieve these days.Its diverse inspirations give Darkwood a well-rounded approach to the genre, providing something enticing for every flavor of gamer. Its RPG roots have inspired the developers to include a skill-tree to the game, allowing character diversification and specialization. The looting and crafting systems are reminiscent of many survival games, from Minecraft to Fortnite, but are presented in their own uniquely gritty ways. My Rating 8/10

Early Access Review
								Gave this game a new try but still boring and after waiting for months feels like there is not much hope for this coming for a full game.. I recently have  been really negative to games who are still EARLY ACCESS after 2 YEARS.. it feels like no one cares if this game come out as a full release but there is many games as The Forest, and other survival games. I have owned this game for 2 years now and I have to say that lets wait a next 2 to 6 years and lets see does this game then have something that actually keep the new and old players active. I know I get lots of negative comment down but this is just my opinion and to all of you developer has been nice to me so I dont judge him or his team, but the main point is this game is not ment for me so might work for you.
